meanings.def: of high quality or an acceptable standard
examples: a good book
good food
The piano was in really good condition.
Your work is just not good enough.
The results were pretty good.
Sorry, my English is not very good.
They've done a reasonably good job.
Keep up the good work!
It's a good way to make friends.
The sound and picture are both of good quality.
Things are looking good at the moment.
You'll never marry her—she's much too good for you.
This essay really is very good.
The food was surprisingly good.
I think that make of car's pretty good.
Her school report was much better this year.
He doesn't seem to have a very good diet.
a really good film
Citrus fruits are a good source of vitamin C.
Why ruin a perfectly good story?
You've done a pretty good job.
Get yourself a haircut and a good suit before the interview.
She gives a good performance as the innocent young woman.

meanings.def: pleasant; that you enjoy or want
examples: Did you have a good time in London?
This is very good news.
Let's hope we have good weather tomorrow.
it is good to do something It's good to see you again.
There are loads of good things about working here.
We are still friends, though, which is good.
It'd be a good place to go on holiday, but not to live in.
It would be good if he moved to London.
In good weather, they sometimes went riding.
If the weather's good, we can take a picnic.
‘What was the weather like on your holiday?’ ‘Good.’

meanings.def: sensible, logical or strongly supporting what is being discussed
examples: Thank you, good question.
Yes, that's a good point.
I have good reason to be suspicious.
What a good idea!
This is a good example of what I mean.
You raised several good points in your letter.
You'll have to think of a better excuse than that!
That's a really good idea.
My father once gave me some good advice.
‘But where are we going to stay?’ ‘That's a very good question.’
‘They won't be able to find the way without a map.’ ‘ Good point.’

meanings.def: showing or getting approval or respect
examples: The play had good reviews.
The hotel has a good reputation.
He comes from a good family.
Initial reactions to the proposal have been good so far.
We got a pretty good response from our viewers about the programme.
The school has an extremely good reputation.

meanings.def: able to do something well
examples: a good player
a good actor/cook
good at something to be good at languages/your job
good at doing something Nick has always been good at finding cheap flights.
She's a really good actor.
I'm not really a very good cook.
She's getting quite good at reading now.
Are you any good at languages?

meanings.def: able to use something or deal with people well
examples: She's good with her hands (= able to make things, etc.).
He's very good with children.
She's good with figures.

meanings.def: morally right; behaving in a way that is morally right
examples: She has tried to lead a good life.
I took Sarah's children to school so I've done my good deed for the day.
Giving her that money was a good thing to do.
He is a very good man.
She prayed that God would make her a better person.

meanings.def: following strictly a set of rules or principles
examples: It is good practice to supply a written report to the buyer.
She was a good Catholic girl.

meanings.def: willing to help; kind to other people
examples: You've always been such a good friend.
good to somebody He was very good to me when I was ill.
good of somebody She looked into it for me, which was very good of her.
good of somebody to do something It was very good of you to come.
good about something I had to take a week off work but my colleagues were very good about it.

meanings.def: behaving well or politely
examples: You can stay up late if you're good.
Get dressed now, there's a good girl.
‘That's a good dog,’ I said, patting its head.
I want you all to be good while I'm out of the room.
She's usually quite good in class.

meanings.def: healthy or strong
examples: Can you speak into my good ear?
I don't feel too good today.
‘How are you?’ ‘I'm good.’ (= used as a general reply to a greeting)

meanings.def: having a useful or helpful effect on somebody/something
examples: Living so close to a chemicals factory can't be good.
good for somebody/something Too much sun isn't good for you.
Vegetables are good for you.
policies that are good for business
The deal will be good for the country as a whole.
it is good for somebody/something to do something It's probably good for you to get some criticism now and then.
(informal) Shut your mouth, if you know what's good for you (= used as a threat).

meanings.def: suitable or appropriate
examples: Now is a good time to buy a house.
Do you really think this is a good use of your time?
Students are not allowed to miss classes without good reason.
good for something/to do something She would be good for the job.
good for somebody Can we change our meeting? Monday isn't good (= convenient) for me.
This is as good a place as any to spend the night.

meanings.def: used in speaking to show that you approve of or are pleased about something that has been said or done, or to show that you want to move on to a new topic of conversation
examples: ‘Dinner's ready.’ ‘Good—I'm starving.’
‘I got the job.’ ‘Oh, good.’
Good, I think we've come to a decision.

meanings.def: used as a form of praise
examples: Good old Jack!
‘I've ordered some drinks.’ ‘Good man!’

meanings.def: used in exclamations
examples: Good heavens!
Good God!

meanings.def: great in number, amount or degree
examples: a good number of people
The kitchen is a good size.
We spent a good while (= quite a long time) looking for the house.
He devoted a good deal of (= a lot of) attention to the problem.
There's a good chance (= it is likely) that I won't be here next year.

meanings.def: not less than; rather more than
examples: We waited for a good hour.
It's a good three miles to the station.

meanings.def: done to a high level or a great degree; complete
examples: We had a good laugh about it afterwards.
You'll feel better after a good sleep.

meanings.def: funny or clever
examples: a good story/joke
(informal) That's a good one!

meanings.def: having enough energy, health, strength, etc. to last for a particular length of time or distance
examples: You're good for (= you will live) a few years yet.

meanings.def: acceptable for something
examples: The ticket is good for three months.

meanings.def: likely to provide something
examples: He's always good for a laugh.
Bobby should be good for a few drinks.

meanings.def: very nearly
examples: The matter is as good as settled.
He as good as called me a coward (= suggested that I was a coward without actually using the word ‘coward’).
She’s as good as won.

meanings.def: used when you are saying that a situation is not going to get any better
(of a thing) to be prepared and ready for use; (of a person) to be prepared and ready to do something
examples: By tomorrow afternoon the document will be good to go.
I’ve spent several months training for this race so now I’m good to go.

meanings.def: completely
examples: I won't go until I'm good and ready.

meanings.def: several
examples: There are still a good few empty seats.

meanings.def: used to praise somebody for doing something well
examples: ‘I passed first time.’ ‘Good for you!’

meanings.def: a lot of somebody/something
examples: There were a good many people there.
The matter is as good as settled.
He as good as called me a coward (= suggested that I was a coward without actually using the word ‘coward’).
She’s as good as won.

idioms.def: used when you are saying that a situation is not going to get any better
(of a thing) to be prepared and ready for use; (of a person) to be prepared and ready to do something
examples: By tomorrow afternoon the document will be good to go.
I’ve spent several months training for this race so now I’m good to go.
I won't go until I'm good and ready.
There are still a good few empty seats.

idioms.idiom: good for you, somebody, them, etc.
idioms.def: used to praise somebody for doing something well
examples: ‘I passed first time.’ ‘Good for you!’
There were a good many people there.

meanings.def: behaviour that is morally right or acceptable
examples: Do they even know the difference between good and evil?
Is religion always a force for good?
The charity does a lot of good.
the difference between good and evil.
Her goodness shone through.
In disadvantaged areas, schools can be a force for good.
the struggle between good and evil
Schools can definitely be seen as a force for good in this area.

meanings.def: people who live a moral life; people who are admired for the work they do to help other people
examples: a gathering of the great and the good

meanings.def: something that helps somebody/something
examples: for the good of somebody/something Cuts have been made for the good of the company.
I'm only telling you this for your own good.
The results of the research should be used for the common good (= the advantage of everyone).
policy decisions that serve the public good
What's the good of (= how does it help you) earning all that money if you don't have time to enjoy it?
What good is it redecorating if you're thinking of moving?
I know you don't want to go into hospital, but it's for your own good.
When the his health problems continued, he resigned for the good of the party.

meanings.def: used to say that if something happens, it will be good, even if it is not exactly what you were expecting
examples: If these measures also reduce unemployment, that is all to the good.

meanings.def: to not be useful; to have no useful effect
examples: This gadget isn't much good.
It's no good complaining—they never listen.
It's no good trying to talk me out of leaving.
This book is no good to me: I need the new edition.
Was his advice ever any good?

meanings.def: to not be interesting or fun
examples: His latest film isn't much good.

meanings.def: to do things that are morally good, especially by helping others
examples: It's nice to get recognition for doing good in the community.
Look for an opportunity to do good whenever you can.

meanings.def: to have a useful effect; to help somebody
examples: Do you think these latest changes will do any good?
Don't you think talking to her would do some good?
It will do you good to get out of the house more often.
You can try talking to her, but I don't think it will do much good.
What good would it do to tell her about it after all this time?

meanings.def: to be very good for somebody’s physical or mental health
examples: A break would do us all a power of good.

meanings.def: to make somebody feel much better; to improve something
examples: A change of job would do you the world of good.

meanings.def: permanently
examples: This time she's leaving for good (= she will never return).
I'd like an excuse to get rid of him for good and all.

meanings.def: people who are very successful, admired and respected
examples: Universities around the world award honorary degrees to the great and the good.

meanings.def: no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody
used to say that somebody now has a particular amount of money that they did not have before
examples: We are £500 to the good.

meanings.def: doing something wrong or dishonest
examples: Those kids are always up to no good.

idioms.def: used to say that if something happens, it will be good, even if it is not exactly what you were expecting
examples: If these measures also reduce unemployment, that is all to the good.

idioms.idiom: be no good (doing something/to somebody) | not be any/much good
idioms.def: to not be useful; to have no useful effect
examples: This gadget isn't much good.
It's no good complaining—they never listen.
It's no good trying to talk me out of leaving.
This book is no good to me: I need the new edition.
Was his advice ever any good?
His latest film isn't much good.

idioms.def: to do things that are morally good, especially by helping others
examples: It's nice to get recognition for doing good in the community.
Look for an opportunity to do good whenever you can.
Do you think these latest changes will do any good?
Don't you think talking to her would do some good?
It will do you good to get out of the house more often.
You can try talking to her, but I don't think it will do much good.
What good would it do to tell her about it after all this time?

idioms.idiom: do somebody a power of good
idioms.def: to be very good for somebody’s physical or mental health
examples: A break would do us all a power of good.

idioms.idiom: do somebody/something the world of good
idioms.def: to make somebody feel much better; to improve something
examples: A change of job would do you the world of good.
This time she's leaving for good (= she will never return).
I'd like an excuse to get rid of him for good and all.

idioms.def: people who are very successful, admired and respected
examples: Universities around the world award honorary degrees to the great and the good.

idioms.idiom: it’s an ill wind (that blows nobody any good)
idioms.def: no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody
used to say that somebody now has a particular amount of money that they did not have before
examples: We are £500 to the good.
Those kids are always up to no good.

meanings.def: well
examples: ‘How's it going?’ ‘Pretty good.’
I'm doing good.
Now, you listen to me good!
